verses.text: I will exalt you, my God and King, and bless your name forever and ever.
verses.comment: David begins with personal praise, signifying close relationship with the Lord as eternal King. The language echoes the idea of worship across generations.

verses.text: Every day I will bless You and praise Your name forever and ever.
verses.comment: The continual nature of praise reminds believers to uphold daily devotion, likely hinting at a liturgical life of regular prayer.

verses.text: Great is the LORD, and greatly to be praised; His greatness is beyond searching out.
verses.comment: The majesty of God exceeds human comprehension. This points to the mystery of the divine nature, later reflected in Christ’s incarnation (cf. Col. 1:15–17).

verses.text: One generation shall praise Your works to another, and shall declare Your mighty acts.
verses.comment: Passing down the faith is central; spiritual inheritance is emphasized, showing the importance of tradition.

verses.text: I will meditate on the glorious splendor of Your majesty, and on Your wondrous works.
verses.comment: Contemplation is highlighted; this verse encourages reflection and awe, which deepens love for God’s mysteries.

verses.text: People will speak of the power of Your awesome deeds, and I will declare Your greatness.
verses.comment: The sharing of God’s wonders is a communal act, subtly highlighting the unity of believers in worship.

verses.text: They shall pour forth the memory of Your abundant goodness and will sing of Your righteousness.
verses.comment: Remembrance and song are ways the community celebrates divine goodness, suggesting spiritual songs as part of worship’s regular pattern.

verses.text: The LORD is gracious and merciful, slow to anger and abounding in steadfast love.
verses.comment: This description repeats a foundational revelation of God’s character in the Old Testament, fulfilled perfectly in Christ’s mercy (cf. John 1:14–17).

verses.text: The LORD is good to all, and His compassion is over all that He has made.
verses.comment: God’s universal kindness foreshadows the invitation to salvation for all nations, realized in the New Testament (cf. Acts 10:34–35).

verses.text: All Your works give thanks to You, O LORD, and Your faithful ones bless You.
verses.comment: Creation and the community of believers together respond to God—a pattern for the unity of worship seen in later liturgical practice.

verses.text: They speak of the glory of Your kingdom and tell of Your power.
verses.comment: The kingdom is a central theme tying old and new covenants; pointing toward Christ’s reign (cf. Luke 1:33).

verses.text: To make known to mankind Your mighty deeds and the glorious majesty of Your kingdom.
verses.comment: The call to proclaim the kingdom prefigures Christ’s command to evangelize and the visible manifestation of God’s reign.

verses.text: Your kingdom is an everlasting kingdom, and Your dominion endures throughout all generations. The LORD is faithful in all His words and gracious in all His deeds.
verses.comment: A messianic promise, highlighting an eternal kingdom fulfilled in Christ. Ancient manuscripts sometimes include 'faithful in all His words...' as a later addition, but it aligns with God’s covenant faithfulness.

verses.text: The LORD upholds all who are falling and raises up all who are bowed down.
verses.comment: Divine help for the humble echoes Christ’s teaching on humility (cf. Matt. 11:28–30).

verses.text: The eyes of all look to You, and You give them their food at the proper time.
verses.comment: God’s providence is universal and timely. This foreshadows spiritual nourishment, pointing subtly to eucharistic themes in later worship.

verses.text: You open Your hand and satisfy the desire of every living thing.
verses.comment: The abundance from God’s hand points toward the grace bestowed on all creation, including spiritual blessings.

verses.text: The LORD is righteous in all His ways and kind in all His works.
verses.comment: God’s righteousness is both a standard and a gift; it reflects both the justice and the mercy shown in redemption.

verses.text: The LORD is near to all who call on Him, to all who call on Him in truth.
verses.comment: This verse teaches the accessibility of God through sincere prayer, anticipating deeper relationship through sacramental communion.

verses.text: He fulfills the desire of those who fear Him; He hears their cry and saves them.
verses.comment: The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom and leads to salvation; a relational dynamic encouraged by Christ (cf. Luke 1:50).

verses.text: The LORD preserves all who love Him, but all the wicked He will destroy.
verses.comment: God’s care for the righteous mirrors the New Testament’s promise of eternal life and judgment.

verses.text: My mouth shall speak the praise of the LORD, and let all flesh bless His holy name forever and ever.
verses.comment: Concludes with a universal call to worship that transcends individual prayer, inviting all peoples—later fulfilled in the worship of the global church.
